overview: Married Couple’s Allowance reduces your tax bill - what you'll get, eligibility and applying
title: Married Couple's Allowance

table.body:
Married Couple's Allowance could reduce your tax bill by £296 to £770.50 a year.

You can claim Married Couple's Allowance if:

- you're married or in a civil partnership 
- you're living with your spouse or civil partner
- one of you was born before 6 April 1935

For marriages before 5 December 2005, the husband's income is used to work out Married Couple's Allowance. For marriage and civil partnerships after this date, it's the income of the highest earner.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
Married Couple's Allowance could reduce your tax bill each year you're married or in a civil partnership.

For the 2012 to 2013 tax year, it could cut your tax bill by between £296 and £770.50.

$!Use the [Married Couple's Allowance calculator](/calculate-married-couples-allowance "Married Couple's Allowance calculator") to work out if you qualify and how much you could get.$!

If you marry or register a civil partnership, you'll get the allowance on a pro-rata basis for the rest of that tax year.

If one of you dies or you divorce or separate, the allowance continues until the end of the tax year.

You can [transfer your Married Couple's Allowance](married-couples-allowance/further-information "Further information about Married Couple's Allowance") to your spouse or civil partner.
table.title: What you'll get

table.body:
You can claim Married Couple's Allowance if:

- you're married or in a civil partnership 
- one of you was **born before 6 April 1935**

$!Use the [Married Couple's Allowance calculator](/calculate-married-couples-allowance "Married Couple's Allowance calculator") to work out if you qualify and how much you could get.$!
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
##If you fill in a Self Assessment tax return each year

Claim by completing the Married Couple's Allowance section of the tax return.

##If you don't fill in a Self Assessment tax return each year

Contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC).

You must give them details about your:

- marriage or civil partnership ceremony
- spouse or civil partner - including their date of birth

table.title: How to claim

table.body:
##Transfer unused Married Couple's Allowance after the tax year ends

If your spouse or civil partner pays tax, you can transfer any Married Couple's Allowance that you haven't used because:

- you don’t pay tax
- your tax bill isn't high enough

Fill in Form 575 or contact [HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)](/married-couples-allowance/how-to-claim "Contact HM Revenue & Customs") who can post you a copy. 

$D
[Download 'Form 575 - Notice of transfer of surplus Income Tax allowances' (PDF, 64KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/575-t-man.pdf "Form 575 - Notice of transfer of surplus Income Tax allowances"){:rel="external"} 
$D

##Share or transfer your Married Couple's Allowance before the tax year starts

You and your spouse (or civil partner) can:

- share the minimum Married Couple's Allowance
- transfer the whole of the minimum Married Couple's Allowance from one to the other

Fill in Form 18 before the start of the tax year - you can also contact [HMRC](/married-couples-allowance/how-to-claim "Contact HM Revenue & Customs") to get a copy in the post.

$D
[Download 'Form 18 - Transferring the Married Couple’s Allowance' - (PDF, 88KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/18.pdf "form 18 - Transferring the Married Couple’s Allowance"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Tax allowances and giving to charity

If you pay tax and give money to a UK charity using Gift Aid, let [HMRC](/married-couples-allowance/how-to-claim "HM Revenue & Customs") know. It can increase the tax allowances you get because you're over 65.

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
